ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about the functioning of Congress and how different political factors affect it.

I learned about the inner workings of Congress and the way that Congress interacts with the other branches of government.  I learned how to write succinct and informative papers that answered interesting prompts.
Learned a lot about the internal structure of Congress and the external and internal issues facing modern Congresses.

This course helped me develop a deep understanding of all government functions, especially within Congress. It gives you an expansive overview of multiple aspects of the roll Congress plays in our system of government.
The history and structure of Congress, within itself and with relation to the other branches of government.
I developed a general understanding of the way Congress is supposed to work in theory and the way it works in reality.
I learned about how Congress functions and interacts with the other branches of government. I also learned about the founders intent when creating the US government.

Not only did I educate myself more on the policies and legislative decision making processes enforced by the United States Congress, but I also understood the election process our representatives must go through before securing their positions in office

I gained a wide breadth of knowledge of the workings of the U.S. Congress and the interplay between that branch and the other branches of government. The course was mainly discussion based with assignments being writing focused. I continued practicing with researching archival data and implementing it into my writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - manageable workload, interesting material, accessible professor
Weaknesses - time of day, engagement level of other students
Strengths include the content organization which was very efficient, weaknesses include disorganized in-class lectures and a general lack of teaching outside of basic pre-recorded lectures.

Great course! The "discussion leaders" component of the participation grade was great for encouraging class participation and full understanding of the concepts. Paper topics were interesting and engaging.
The readings were manageable and the lectures were very interesting. No weaknesses!

Absolutely no weaknesses, and multiple strengths. Through a plethora of interactive discussion sections, communication skills as well as eloquence in public speaking significantly improved among all the students

I really like the format of watching recorded lectures before class time and using class time to discuss the lecture amongst peers. I think the course could be improved with a more active involvement of the professor or TA in the class discussion. Sometimes discussions could be lacking and stagnate without clear direction from the professor.

Throughout this course, I would have liked to engage with the professor a little more. It could be frustrating to spend the entire course (including every class session) just engaging in discussion led by your peers. Although this did allow for SO much engagement, I might have liked the professor to lead for half of every class, and then let students lead for the rest.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you're interested in government work or working in congress, Professor Fairdosi's experience as a congress staff member will definitely appeal to you. You will know congress inside out by the end of the class, but I do have to say that students that already know a lot about the functioning of the US government may find this class redundant.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone at Yale.  It would be a great class for non majors, and a gut for majors.

Yes I would recommend this class. The content is very interesting and generally good for anyone just looking to try out some political science. Some parts were a little dull, but overall the course was engaging. The workload is very manageable, and grading is fair.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. For anyone interested in learning about Congress, this course is ideal. The readings and lectures were super interesting, which made the in-class discussion super engaging. I really enjoyed taking this class.
Absolutely! A great course for polisci beginners and experts alike, as you learn a lot of the basics and also extend into debate about the topics learned.
Yes, this is a great intro level course with very interesting subject matter, good professor, and low workload.
Yes! Professor Fairdosi was very knowledgeable and engaging. Grading was fair and the readings were doable.

Absolutely!! As a STEM major I would never have thought a class in political science would fascinate me as much as this one did. I was able to gain some knowledge into what our founders intended for this nation's federal government to consist of and apply this knowledge to how it actually looks today. This new interest also has me thinking about how I can apply policy to astronomic research which is allocated and funded by Congress. Wonderful wonderful class

I would recommend this course to someone who was not a political science major and/or had very little knowledge on the U.S. government to begin with. I think some of the lectures can be pretty basic for someone more adept in the subject area. But otherwise it was a versus interesting course and I think a good starting point for learning about Congress.
